title: Zvenigorod
text:
Zvenigorod () is an old <a href="types%20of%20inhabited%20localities%20in%20Russia">town</a> in <a href="Moscow%20Oblast">Moscow Oblast</a>, <a href="Russia">Russia</a>. Population: 
History.
The town's name is based either on a personal name (cf. Zvenislav, Zvenimir) or on a hydronym (cf. the Zvinech, Zvinyaka, Zveniga Rivers); the derivation from "town of ringing (bells)" is a folk etymology.
The community has existed since the 12th century, although its first written mention is dated around 1339, in the last will of Grand Duke of Moscow <a href="Ivan%20I%20of%20Moscow">Ivan I Daniilovich Kalita</a>, in which he says: "Thus, I pass on to my son <a href="Ivan%20II%20of%20Moscow">Ivan</a>: Zvenigorod, Kremchina, <a href="Ruza%2C%20Ruzsky%20District%2C%20Moscow%20Oblast">Ruza</a>..." In the historical records, or annals ( [letopis'] in Russian), Zvenigorod is first mentioned around 1382, soon after <a href="Khan%20%28title%29">khan</a> <a href="Tokhtamysh">Tokhtamysh</a> burnt down Moscow, and destroyed a number of towns on the way, including Zvenigorod.
Zvenigorod rose to prominence in the late 14th century after it was bequeathed by <a href="Dmitry%20Donskoy">Dmitry Donskoy</a> to his <a href="Yury%20of%20Zvenigorod">second son Yuri</a>, who founded his residence on the steep bank of the <a href="Moskva%20River">Moskva River</a>. The local kremlin, called Gorodok, contains the only fully preserved example of 14th-century Muscovite architecture, the Dormition Cathedral (1399). The cathedral's interior features frescoes attributed to <a href="Andrei%20Rublev">Andrei Rublev</a>.
Zvenigorod is primarily remembered for <a href="Muscovite%20Civil%20War">internecine wars waged by Yuri's sons</a> for control of Moscow during the reign of their cousin <a href="Vasily%20II%20of%20Moscow">Vasily II</a> (1425–1462). After their party was defeated, the town was incorporated into the <a href="Grand%20Duchy%20of%20Moscow">Grand Duchy of Moscow</a>.
Zvenigorod was granted town rights in 1784. By the late 19th century, the town gained popularity among the <a href="intelligentsia">intelligentsia</a> as a fashionable <a href="banlieue">banlieue</a> of Moscow. Many extravagant <a href="dacha">dacha</a>s were built in the neighbourhood. Some of these house museums of <a href="Sergey%20Taneyev">Sergey Taneyev</a>, <a href="Anton%20Chekhov">Anton Chekhov</a>, and <a href="Isaac%20Levitan">Isaac Levitan</a>.
During <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> Zvenigorod was near, or on the frontline in the 1941-2 <a href="Battle%20of%20Moscow">Battle of Moscow</a>.
Savvino-Storozhevsky Monastery.
 The <a href="Storozhi%20Monastery">Storozhi Monastery</a> near Zvenigorod was established in 1398 by <a href="Savva%20of%20Storozhi">St. Savva</a>, one of the first disciples of <a href="Sergius%20of%20Radonezh">Sergius of Radonezh</a>. The oldest church is the <a href="katholikon">katholikon</a> completed in 1405 and dedicated to the feast of the <a href="Nativity%20of%20the%20Theotokos">Nativity of the Theotokos</a>. In 1650, the monastery was chosen by <a href="Alexis%20of%20Russia">Tsar Alexis</a> as his suburban residence. In five years, they constructed a white-stone royal palace and a festive chamber for <a href="tsaritsa">tsaritsa</a>. The compound was encircled with stone walls and towers, patterned after those of the <a href="Trinity%20Lavra%20of%20St.%20Sergius">Trinity Lavra of St. Sergius</a>. Particularly noteworthy is a large belfry, erected in four bays in 1650 and crowned with three tents and a clocktower. A church over the holy gates was consecrated to the <a href="Trinity">Holy Trinity</a> in 1652.
After the death of <a href="Feodor%20III%20of%20Russia">Feodor III</a>, who spent most of his time there, the monastery declined. In May 1918, when the <a href="Bolshevik">Bolshevik</a>s tried to seize the relics of St. Savva, several persons were shot dead. In 1985, the cloister was assigned to the <a href="Danilov%20Monastery">Danilov Monastery</a> in Moscow. St. Savva's relics were returned to the monastery in 1998.
Administrative and municipal status.
Within the <a href="subdivisions%20of%20Russia%23Administrative%20divisions">framework of administrative divisions</a>, it is incorporated as Zvenigorod <a href="City%20of%20federal%20subject%20significance">Town Under Oblast Jurisdiction</a>—an administrative unit with the status equal to that of the <a href="administrative%20divisions%20of%20Moscow%20Oblast">districts</a>. As a <a href="subdivisions%20of%20Russia%23Municipal%20divisions">municipal division</a>, Zvenigorod Town Under Oblast Jurisdiction is incorporated as Zvenigorod Urban Okrug.
Sport.
The city has a woman's handball team <a href="Zvezda%20Zvenigorod">Zvezda Zvenigorod</a>"," which won the <a href="Women%27s%20EHF%20Champions%20League">Women's EHF Champions League</a> in the 2007–08 season.
